title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #833:** Does every r-uniform 3-chromatic hypergraph have a vertex in at least (1+c)^r edges for some absolute c > 0?

**Answer:** YES! Erdős-Lovász (1975) proved the bound 2^{r-1}/(4r), confirming exponential growth.

title: UniformHypergraph
content:
**r-uniform hypergraph:** H = (V, E) where every edge e in E has exactly r vertices.

Examples: r = 2 is ordinary graphs, r = 3 is triple systems.

title: vertexDegree
content:
**Vertex degree:** Number of edges containing vertex v.

deg(v) = |{e in E : v in e}|

title: IsProperColoring
content:
**Proper k-coloring:** Assigns colors 1..k to vertices so no edge is monochromatic.

For hypergraphs: every edge contains at least two vertices of different colors.

title: HasChromaticNumber3
content:
**Chromatic number 3:** H is NOT 2-colorable but IS 3-colorable.

This is the minimal non-bipartite case for hypergraphs.

title: f(r) Function
content:
**f(r):** Minimum over all r-uniform 3-chromatic hypergraphs H of the maximum vertex degree in H.

Every such H has a vertex in at least f(r) edges.

title: Known Values
content:
**Known:** f(2) = 2 (triangle), f(3) = 3 (Fano plane).

Erdős did not know f(4).

title: Exponential Growth Conjecture
content:
**Conjecture:** There exists c > 0 such that f(r) >= (1+c)^r for all r >= 2.

Does vertex degree grow exponentially with uniformity?

title: Erdős-Lovász Theorem
content:
**Erdős-Lovász (1975):** Every r-uniform 3-chromatic hypergraph has a vertex in at least 2^{r-1}/(4r) edges.

This grows like (sqrt(2))^r, confirming exponential growth!

title: f(r) Lower Bound
content:
**Corollary:** f(r) >= floor(2^{r-1}/(4r)).

This is exponential in r with base sqrt(2) approx 1.414.

title: Bound is Exponential
content:
**Key insight:** 2^{r-1}/(4r) >= (sqrt(2) - epsilon)^r for large r.

The polynomial factor 1/r is dominated by the exponential.

title: Main Result
content:
**Theorem:** ExponentialGrowthConjecture is TRUE.

Take c = 0.4 (so 1+c = 1.4 < sqrt(2)). The Erdős-Lovász bound implies the conjecture.

title: High Degree Vertex Exists
content:
**Corollary:** Every 3-chromatic r-uniform H has a vertex v with deg(v) >= 2^{r-1}/(4r).

Direct application of the main bound.

title: Triangle Example
content:
**f(2) = 2:** The triangle (K_3) is 3-chromatic with all vertices having degree 2.

This is the minimal 3-chromatic graph.

title: Fano Plane
content:
**f(3) = 3:** The Fano plane is a 3-uniform hypergraph with 7 vertices, 7 edges, chromatic number 3, and all degrees = 3.

It's the projective plane PG(2,2).

title: Lovász Local Lemma
content:
**Proof technique:** If all vertex degrees are small, a random 2-coloring avoids monochromatic edges with positive probability.

Contradicts chi(H) = 3, so some degree must be large.

title: Contrapositive Form
content:
**Contrapositive:** If all deg(v) < 2^{r-1}/(4r), then H is 2-colorable.

So chi(H) = 3 implies some vertex has high degree.

title: erdos_833
content:
**Complete Result:**
1. ExponentialGrowthConjecture holds (c approx 0.4)
2. Specific bound: 2^{r-1}/(4r) for every 3-chromatic r-uniform H

PROBLEM SOLVED by Erdős-Lovász (1975).
